data.descriptionText: Run 2 new data cables from existing outlets to new desk positions.

Emergency lighting systems should be tested regularly in the UK to ensure that they are in good working order and able to provide adequate illumination in the event of an emergency. The monthly functional test is a quick and simple check that can be carried out by the building owner or manager. The test involves switching off the mains power to the emergency lighting system and checking that the emergency lights come on and remain illuminated. If any faults or issues are identified during the monthly test, they should be addressed as soon as possible.  How do you Test Emergency Lighting?There are different ways to test emergency lighting in the UK, depending on the type of emergency lighting system and the requirements of the relevant regulations and standards. However, the following is a general procedure for testing emergency lighting: Emergency Monthly TestingThe monthly test is a functional test that checks that the emergency lighting system is working correctly. To carry out the monthly test, you should:Simulate a power failure by either an emergency key switch or by switching off the mains power to the emergency lighting.Observe that the emergency lighting comes on automatically.Check that the emergency lights remain illuminated for the required duration (usually 10 minutes or as required by the relevant regulations or standards).Record the results of the test on Simpro and in the emergency log book if applicable. Asset ID 3599 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 14/11/2025Asset ID 3632 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 14/11/2025

Temperatures of outlets to be tested on a monthly basis. Checking the temperature from the hot tapsUsing an accurate thermometer, check the water flow from a chosen hot tap. When doing this for the first time, the tap furthest away from the calorifier/water heater/boiler should be chosen, this is sometimes called a sentinel outlet.Other representative points can then also be checked in a chosen pattern, eventually repeating the pattern so different taps are checked monthly.Here are the main points to note:Hold the thermometer in the hot water flow for one minuteRecord the temperature on the thermometerIt should be a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius after one minuteIf it is below this, advise whoever oversees the site so the necessary actions can be taken to remedy the issueIf thermostatic mixing valves (TMVs) are fitted, these ensure the temperature never exceeds 44 degrees Celsius primarily to prevent hot water scalding. In this case, the hot water inlet to the TMV should be checked instead of the hot taps. Again, a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius should be recorded in this instance.With a TMV fitted water temperatures at the hot tap should not exceed 44 degrees Celsius.Checking the temperature from water heaters (calorifiers)On a monthly basis check the water flow and return temperatures at water heaters (calorifiers). One way of measuring these temperatures is to use a surface temperature probe. The outgoing water should be at least 60 °C in order to kill Legionella bacteria.Temperatures from cold tapsA similar pattern should be followed to that described for hot water above. Formulate a pattern for rotating through different cold taps each month:Hold the thermometer in the cold water flow for two minutesRecord the temperature after two minutesIt should be a maximum of 20 degrees Celsius or belowReport and action as above if it goes above thisOther water checks to makeMake a monthly check of water temperatures of the flow and return from and to the calorifier (see above).Keeping accurate records is of paramount importance.Asset ID 2849 - Asset Type Water Meter - Service Level Daily - Service Due Date 21/11/2025

Emergency lighting systems should be tested regularly in the UK to ensure that they are in good working order and able to provide adequate illumination in the event of an emergency. The monthly functional test is a quick and simple check that can be carried out by the building owner or manager. The test involves switching off the mains power to the emergency lighting system and checking that the emergency lights come on and remain illuminated. If any faults or issues are identified during the monthly test, they should be addressed as soon as possible.  How do you Test Emergency Lighting?There are different ways to test emergency lighting in the UK, depending on the type of emergency lighting system and the requirements of the relevant regulations and standards. However, the following is a general procedure for testing emergency lighting: Emergency Monthly TestingThe monthly test is a functional test that checks that the emergency lighting system is working correctly. To carry out the monthly test, you should:Simulate a power failure by either an emergency key switch or by switching off the mains power to the emergency lighting.Observe that the emergency lighting comes on automatically.Check that the emergency lights remain illuminated for the required duration (usually 10 minutes or as required by the relevant regulations or standards).Record the results of the test on Simpro and in the emergency log book if applicable. Asset ID 3666 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 14/11/2025Asset ID 3665 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 14/11/2025Asset ID 3667 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 14/11/2025Asset ID 3670 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 14/11/2025Asset ID 3698 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 14/11/2025Asset ID 3731 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 14/11/2025Asset ID 3732 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 14/11/2025

Temperatures of outlets to be tested on a monthly basis. Checking the temperature from the hot tapsUsing an accurate thermometer, check the water flow from a chosen hot tap. When doing this for the first time, the tap furthest away from the calorifier/water heater/boiler should be chosen, this is sometimes called a sentinel outlet.Other representative points can then also be checked in a chosen pattern, eventually repeating the pattern so different taps are checked monthly.Here are the main points to note:Hold the thermometer in the hot water flow for one minuteRecord the temperature on the thermometerIt should be a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius after one minuteIf it is below this, advise whoever oversees the site so the necessary actions can be taken to remedy the issueIf thermostatic mixing valves (TMVs) are fitted, these ensure the temperature never exceeds 44 degrees Celsius primarily to prevent hot water scalding. In this case, the hot water inlet to the TMV should be checked instead of the hot taps. Again, a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius should be recorded in this instance.With a TMV fitted water temperatures at the hot tap should not exceed 44 degrees Celsius.Checking the temperature from water heaters (calorifiers)On a monthly basis check the water flow and return temperatures at water heaters (calorifiers). One way of measuring these temperatures is to use a surface temperature probe. The outgoing water should be at least 60 °C in order to kill Legionella bacteria.Temperatures from cold tapsA similar pattern should be followed to that described for hot water above. Formulate a pattern for rotating through different cold taps each month:Hold the thermometer in the cold water flow for two minutesRecord the temperature after two minutesIt should be a maximum of 20 degrees Celsius or belowReport and action as above if it goes above thisOther water checks to makeMake a monthly check of water temperatures of the flow and return from and to the calorifier (see above).Keeping accurate records is of paramount importance.Asset ID 3533 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 13/11/2025Asset ID 3538 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 13/11/2025Asset ID 3543 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 13/11/2025Asset ID 3544 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 13/11/2025Asset ID 3547 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 13/11/2025Asset ID 3550 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 13/11/2025Asset ID 3551 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 13/11/2025Asset ID 3557 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 13/11/2025Asset ID 3558 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 13/11/2025Asset ID 3561 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 13/11/2025

Emergency lighting systems should be tested regularly in the UK to ensure that they are in good working order and able to provide adequate illumination in the event of an emergency. The monthly functional test is a quick and simple check that can be carried out by the building owner or manager. The test involves switching off the mains power to the emergency lighting system and checking that the emergency lights come on and remain illuminated. If any faults or issues are identified during the monthly test, they should be addressed as soon as possible.  How do you Test Emergency Lighting?There are different ways to test emergency lighting in the UK, depending on the type of emergency lighting system and the requirements of the relevant regulations and standards. However, the following is a general procedure for testing emergency lighting: Emergency Monthly TestingThe monthly test is a functional test that checks that the emergency lighting system is working correctly. To carry out the monthly test, you should:Simulate a power failure by either an emergency key switch or by switching off the mains power to the emergency lighting.Observe that the emergency lighting comes on automatically.Check that the emergency lights remain illuminated for the required duration (usually 10 minutes or as required by the relevant regulations or standards).Record the results of the test on Simpro and in the emergency log book if applicable. Asset ID 3666 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025Asset ID 3665 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025Asset ID 3667 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025Asset ID 3670 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025Asset ID 3732 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025Asset ID 3731 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025Asset ID 3698 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025

Charlie Bowyer (12/11/2025) - Work NoteResealed rubber washer on siphon
Investigation of hot water / boiler, nothing seemed to be faulty. Looked at the spec for that boiler and preheated water was at the max of 60 degrees.

Boiler fault.John Doidge (22/10/2025) - Work NoteArrive on site to be informed that the boiler started working again this morning. The tenant had reset the boiler. Possible issues with the gas supply being interrupted locally and the boiler locking out because of this. Unable to identify the reason for the fault.
Cold radiator in room 38.John Doidge (18/11/2025) - Work NoteRadiator was found to be hot. Check operation of the TRV.
Cold radiator in room 37.John Doidge (18/11/2025) - Work NoteRadiator in room 37 was found to be hot. Check operation of the TRV.

Radiator in bedroom does not get hot.John Doidge (18/11/2025) - Work NoteBleed air from the towel radiator in the bathroom. Also free-up the stuck thermostatic pin on the TRV in the rear bedroom. Both are now hot.

Boiler pressure is low.John Doidge (19/11/2025) - Work NoteBoiler pressure found to be at zero. Top up to 1.5 bar and vent air from all of the radiators. Adjust the boiler pressure to 1.2 bar and test operation. The boilers heating set point was set to 44C. This has been adjusted to 65C. All radiators are now getting hot.

Sitting room bedroom radiator faulty TRV. Luke Trevatt (21/11/2025) - Work NoteAttended site to in vestigated the highlighted isues with TRV radiator valves within Dames property, unfortunately due to it being the Dames day off, after speaking to the house master it was requested she not be disturbed. Visit to be re scheduled.

Kitchen tap is loose.John Doidge (23/12/2025) - Work NoteKitchen tap found to have a loose spout and to be loose on the worktop counter. Re-fix the spout and tighten. Also tighten the tap to the worktop.
Radiator bathroom is cold.John Doidge (23/12/2025) - Work NoteBleed air from the bathroom towel rail.
Room 45. Damaged tap.John Doidge (24/12/2025) - Work NoteTap found to be loose to the basin. Tighten both securing nuts.
Leaking taps - second floorLuke Trevatt (17/12/2025) - Work NoteI have had to abort job as keys for job would not open side gate to gain entrance ,to be re scheduled.
Heating fault. Low pressure.John Doidge (02/01/2026) - Work NoteFault had already been rectified by the tenant.

Radiator stopt heating againLuke Trevatt (08/01/2026) - Work NoteI re-attended the ladies office that TRV, Was stuck down this has been fully opened as client had have closed, the olt type Trv needs replacing, although at present the entire system is hot on district heating and black iron pipe could not be frozen until cool in Spring when heating not on for period of time, this is a 1/2 inch black iron pipe threaded so valve requires female thread to 3/4 connection. Heating left on fully and very hot.
Radiators cold. G/floor play garden roomLuke Trevatt (14/01/2026) - Work NoteAttended property radiators vented, no further issues .

Emergency lighting systems should be tested regularly in the UK to ensure that they are in good working order and able to provide adequate illumination in the event of an emergency. The monthly functional test is a quick and simple check that can be carried out by the building owner or manager. The test involves switching off the mains power to the emergency lighting system and checking that the emergency lights come on and remain illuminated. If any faults or issues are identified during the monthly test, they should be addressed as soon as possible.  How do you Test Emergency Lighting?There are different ways to test emergency lighting in the UK, depending on the type of emergency lighting system and the requirements of the relevant regulations and standards. However, the following is a general procedure for testing emergency lighting: Emergency Monthly TestingThe monthly test is a functional test that checks that the emergency lighting system is working correctly. To carry out the monthly test, you should:Simulate a power failure by either an emergency key switch or by switching off the mains power to the emergency lighting.Observe that the emergency lighting comes on automatically.Check that the emergency lights remain illuminated for the required duration (usually 10 minutes or as required by the relevant regulations or standards).Record the results of the test on Simpro and in the emergency log book if applicable. Asset ID 3768 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025Asset ID 3769 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025Asset ID 3770 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025Asset ID 3771 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025Asset ID 3772 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025Asset ID 3773 - Asset Type Emergency Light - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 22/12/2025

Asset ID 5353 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 02/01/2026Asset ID 5359 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 02/01/2026Asset ID 5362 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 02/01/2026Asset ID 5367 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due DaTemperatures of outlets to be tested on a monthly basis. Checking the temperature from the hot tapsUsing an accurate thermometer, check the water flow from a chosen hot tap. When doing this for the first time, the tap furthest away from the calorifier/water heater/boiler should be chosen, this is sometimes called a sentinel outlet.Other representative points can then also be checked in a chosen pattern, eventually repeating the pattern so different taps are checked monthly.Here are the main points to note:Hold the thermometer in the hot water flow for one minuteRecord the temperature on the thermometerIt should be a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius after one minuteIf it is below this, advise whoever oversees the site so the necessary actions can be taken to remedy the issueIf thermostatic mixing valves (TMVs) are fitted, these ensure the temperature never exceeds 44 degrees Celsius primarily to prevent hot water scalding. In this case, the hot water inlet to the TMV should be checked instead of the hot taps. Again, a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius should be recorded in this instance.With a TMV fitted water temperatures at the hot tap should not exceed 44 degrees Celsius.Checking the temperature from water heaters (calorifiers)On a monthly basis check the water flow and return temperatures at water heaters (calorifiers). One way of measuring these temperatures is to use a surface temperature probe. The outgoing water should be at least 60 °C in order to kill Legionella bacteria.Temperatures from cold tapsA similar pattern should be followed to that described for hot water above. Formulate a pattern for rotating through different cold taps each month:Hold the thermometer in the cold water flow for two minutesRecord the temperature after two minutesIt should be a maximum of 20 degrees Celsius or belowReport and action as above if it goes above thisOther water checks to makeMake a monthly check of water temperatures of the flow and return from and to the calorifier (see above).Keeping accurate records is of paramount importance.te 02/01/2026

When doing this for the first time, the tap furthest away from the calorifier/water heater/boiler should be chosen, this is sometimes called a sentinel outlet.Other representative points can then also be checked in a chosen pattern, eventually repeating the pattern so different taps are checked monthly.Here are the main points to note:Hold the thermometer in the hot water flow for one minuteRecord the temperature on the thermometerIt should be a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius after one minuteIf it is below this, advise whoever oversees the site so the necessary actions can be taken to remedy the issueIf thermostatic mixing valves (TMVs) are fitted, these ensure the temperature never exceeds 44 degrees Celsius primarily to prevent hot water scalding. In this case, the hot water inlet to the TMV should be checked instead of the hot taps. Again, a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius should be recorded in this instance.With a TMV fitted water temperatures at the hot tap should not exceed 44 degrees Celsius.Checking the temperature from water heaters (calorifiers)On a monthly basis check the water flow and return temperatures at water heaters (calorifiers). One way of measuring these temperatures is to use a surface temperature probe. The outgoing water should be at least 60 °C in order to kill Legionella bacteria.Temperatures from cold tapsA similar pattern should be followed to that described for hot water above. Formulate a pattern for rotating through different cold taps each month:Hold the thermometer in the cold water flow for two minutesRecord the temperature after two minutesIt should be a maximum of 20 degrees Celsius or belowReport and action as above if it goes above thisOther water checks to makeMake a monthly check of water temperatures of the flow and return from and to the calorifier (see above).Keeping accurate records is of paramount importance.Asset ID 4985 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4987 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4990 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4992 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4995 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4996 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4998 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 5001 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 5002 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 5005 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025

Callum Jones (06/01/2026) - Work NoteAttended site to look into possible avenues to supply the recently installed CCTV camera on the front of the building. The most likely solution is to run in a new circuit from the existing Memsheild 2 DB in the main cupboard to feed a metal clad non switched fuse spur in the cupboard before feeding the camera on the external wall.We will require clarification on where the supply will need to be connected to, I presume it’s will be the plastic adaptable box adjacent to the to camera but no one on site could give me a definitive answer.Additionally they have requested that we mount 3x parking signs to the wall at the front of the building.

data.siteName: Padel Pavilion  Braywick Rd  Maidenhead  SL6 1BN
data.descriptionText: Phil Basford - Enquiry phone Call @ 10am 06.01.26 1) Site survey to investigate and propose the control of court lighting to facilitate opening hours of 0600hrs to 2400hrs. Please take photos of existing control set up and the exact client requirements so we can propose a solution.  2) Site survey to investigate and propose an access control solution to facilitate extended opening hours without Padel staff being present. I have sent an enquiry email to a supplier as per below to get things moving so we have some options:  Please could you provide budgetary costs and a technical data sheet for supplying Weblock automatic access facilities to seven paddle courts, similar to the solution shown in your online case study.The courts are located in Maidenhead, Berkshire.In addition, it would be helpful if you could advise on:Typical lead times from order to installationAny infrastructure or power requirementsOngoing maintenance or licensing considerationsWe would also welcome the opportunity for a site visit and demonstration. If possible, please let us know your availability to attend site with a sample unit to review suitability and operation in person.3) Revise the cost for external speakers by reducing the number of speaker points- send over to jade and Phil with lead times etc.  Can we get Ben down there as he is familiar with the site one morning or afternoon this week please.  Additional info: Access control needs to interface with Playtomic add If Playtomic has supplied you with hardware for your keypad entry and lights, then there are a couple of things you should know how to do in your back office. The most important to know is that every reservation, generates a new PIN code for access. The pin code for the reservation is emailed to the player in the reservation confirmation email and can also be found in the app and you can also see this in your back office. IN THE APP IN THE BACK OFFICEBy default the pin code is active 30 mins before the reservation starts during the reservation time and up to 15 mins after. You do have the opportunity to change this in your back office if the above does not suit your players. Just go to Settings > Center and scroll down to this field:  NOTE - You must complete both fields for this to change.  GENERAL ACCESS CODESThese will be used for staff members or alike and you can create your own access codes in SETTINGS > ACCESS CODES. These codes never expire and you can edit and create new ones whenever you need.Hello Andy! Thank you for contacting Playtomic.  My name is Marloes, and I’m happy to help with your enquiry today.  Playtomic doesn’t directly offer an automated access control system, but we do have possible integrations with several companies that provide this kind of solution. To explore these options, just head to your Playtomic Manager dashboard and go to Settings > Integrations > Connect New. There you’ll find a list of providers that can be connected to your Playtomic account. You’ll need to choose the provider you want to work with first. Each company listed will have their own pricing, installation steps, infrastructure needs, and lead times. For details like datasheets, demos, and exact instructions, it’s best to reach out to them directly. Once you pick a provider, they’ll guide you on how to connect their system with Playtomic and provide you with the necessary API key. Once you connect with one of the companies, if you need step-by-step help connecting an integration into Playtomic, you can check out our guide here: How to connect integrations in Playtomic Manager Let me know if you’d like more info or if you have any other questions! Kind regards,Marloes  Playtomic Customer Care Team

Caxton Schools At the time of the visit, the water heater WH 01 had been switched off and the output temperature was only 12.5oC. Once the water heater is switched back on, adjust the thermostat to maximum. Medium  Temperature/Boiler Marten School At the time of the visit, the hot water flow from WH 03 (1st floor boys WC) was only 12.9oC and we suspect a power problem. The College should investigate the water heater so that hot water is supplied to 50oC at least. High  Temperature/Boiler New School WH 03 supplies hot water for the ground floor toilets adjacent to the Canon Yard . In this area, there is a Female WC, Boys WC and a staff WC but the water heater could not be found. At the time of the visit, hot water temperatures in the staff WC was 17.5oC which indicates a problem with this water heater. The water heater should be located and its thermostat adjusted so that the supply water is at least 50oC. High  Temperature/Boiler New School Water heater WH 04, had an output temperature of 33.3oC which is less than the legionella guidelines advice. The water heater thermostat should be increased so that the sink hot water reaches 50oC at any time within 1 minute. High  Temperature/Boiler

data.descriptionText: What is a PPE Inspection?A PPE inspection is a thorough assessment of protective equipment to identify any issues, defects, damages, or wear and tear that could compromise its protective capabilities. It involves systematically examining PPE to ensure its effectiveness in safeguarding individuals against workplace hazards, and whether PPE meets safety standards.The main objectives of PPE inspections are to:Verify that PPE functions properly and safeguards users from hazardsDetect and resolve issues early to prevent failures and reduce costsEnsure compliance with occupational safety regulations and standardsPlease read attached Toolbox Talk, then check all PPE and fill out using audit form found in Pre-audit, Quality Assured, PPE Check.

Temperatures of outlets to be tested on a monthly basis. Checking the temperature from the hot tapsUsing an accurate thermometer, check the water flow from a chosen hot tap. When doing this for the first time, the tap furthest away from the calorifier/water heater/boiler should be chosen, this is sometimes called a sentinel outlet.Other representative points can then also be checked in a chosen pattern, eventually repeating the pattern so different taps are checked monthly.Here are the main points to note:Hold the thermometer in the hot water flow for one minuteRecord the temperature on the thermometerIt should be a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius after one minuteIf it is below this, advise whoever oversees the site so the necessary actions can be taken to remedy the issueIf thermostatic mixing valves (TMVs) are fitted, these ensure the temperature never exceeds 44 degrees Celsius primarily to prevent hot water scalding. In this case, the hot water inlet to the TMV should be checked instead of the hot taps. Again, a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius should be recorded in this instance.With a TMV fitted water temperatures at the hot tap should not exceed 44 degrees Celsius.Checking the temperature from water heaters (calorifiers)On a monthly basis check the water flow and return temperatures at water heaters (calorifiers). One way of measuring these temperatures is to use a surface temperature probe. The outgoing water should be at least 60 °C in order to kill Legionella bacteria.Temperatures from cold tapsA similar pattern should be followed to that described for hot water above. Formulate a pattern for rotating through different cold taps each month:Hold the thermometer in the cold water flow for two minutesRecord the temperature after two minutesIt should be a maximum of 20 degrees Celsius or belowReport and action as above if it goes above thisOther water checks to makeMake a monthly check of water temperatures of the flow and return from and to the calorifier (see above).Keeping accurate records is of paramount importance.Asset ID 5058 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 30/10/2025Asset ID 5060 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 30/10/2025Asset ID 5063 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 30/10/2025Asset ID 5066 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 30/10/2025Asset ID 5069 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 30/10/2025Asset ID 5071 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 30/10/2025Asset ID 5074 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 30/10/2025Asset ID 5076 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 30/10/2025Asset ID 5078 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 30/10/2025Asset ID 5081 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 30/10/2025Asset ID 5084 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 30/10/2025

Formulate a pattern for rotating through different cold taps each month:Hold the thermometer in the cold water flow for two minutesRecord the temperature after two minutesIt should be a maximum of 20 degrees Celsius or belowReport and action as above if it goes above thisOther water checks to makeMake a monthly check of water temperatures of the flow and return from and to the calorifier (see above).Keeping accurate records is of paramount importance.Asset ID 4886 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4887 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4889 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4892 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4895 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4897 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4898 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4901 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4903 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4905 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4908 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4911 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025Asset ID 4914 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 28/10/2025

Asset ID 3930 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 10/11/2025Asset ID 3934 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 10/11/2025Asset ID 3940 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 10/11/2025Asset ID 3945 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 10/11/2025Asset ID 3951 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 10/11/2025Asset ID 3959 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 10/11/2025Asset ID 3973 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 10/11/2025Asset ID 3985 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 10/11/2025Asset ID 3987 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 10/11/2025Asset ID 3994 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 10/11/2025Asset ID 4002 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 10/11/2025Asset ID 4012 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 10/11/2025Temperatures of outlets to be tested on a monthly basis. Checking the temperature from the hot tapsUsing an accurate thermometer, check the water flow from a chosen hot tap. When doing this for the first time, the tap furthest away from the calorifier/water heater/boiler should be chosen, this is sometimes called a sentinel outlet.Other representative points can then also be checked in a chosen pattern, eventually repeating the pattern so different taps are checked monthly.Here are the main points to note:Hold the thermometer in the hot water flow for one minuteRecord the temperature on the thermometerIt should be a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius after one minuteIf it is below this, advise whoever oversees the site so the necessary actions can be taken to remedy the issueIf thermostatic mixing valves (TMVs) are fitted, these ensure the temperature never exceeds 44 degrees Celsius primarily to prevent hot water scalding. In this case, the hot water inlet to the TMV should be checked instead of the hot taps. Again, a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius should be recorded in this instance.With a TMV fitted water temperatures at the hot tap should not exceed 44 degrees Celsius.Checking the temperature from water heaters (calorifiers)On a monthly basis check the water flow and return temperatures at water heaters (calorifiers). One way of measuring these temperatures is to use a surface temperature probe. The outgoing water should be at least 60 °C in order to kill Legionella bacteria.Temperatures from cold tapsA similar pattern should be followed to that described for hot water above. Formulate a pattern for rotating through different cold taps each month:Hold the thermometer in the cold water flow for two minutesRecord the temperature after two minutesIt should be a maximum of 20 degrees Celsius or belowReport and action as above if it goes above thisOther water checks to makeMake a monthly check of water temperatures of the flow and return from and to the calorifier (see above).Keeping accurate records is of paramount importance.

Loose tap in kitchenCasey Bonner (08/10/2025) - Work NoteTighten loose taps
David Collins (09/10/2025) - Work NoteCheck water pressure no faults found in form college staff on site that no hot water as new heater is required. job complete.
David Collins (10/10/2025) - Work NoteTrace fault to electric space heater , take details and dimensions and pass to electrical division. job complete.
David Collins (10/10/2025) - Work NoteCollect from Eton College stores shower waste cover to replace missing one . job complete.
David Collins (14/10/2025) - Work NoteCheck booster set in boiler house pumps boilers found tripped out in panel , reset breaker vent pumps and check operation . job complete.
David Collins (14/10/2025) - Work NoteCheck shower operation no faults found. job complete.

David Collins (15/10/2025) - Work NoteAccess header tank isolate mains remove float valve strip down and re-washer, refit float valve and adjust float level. Turn mains back on check for leaks none found. job complete.
David Collins (15/10/2025) - Work NoteCheck pumps and tank fault in panel , our electrical division are on the case. job complete.

Toilet system not flushing. Luke Trevatt (17/10/2025) - Work NoteAttended 2nd floor single toilet with basin next to room c11. The system was full of water and flushed correctly although after flush the water presure on inlet to systern was very poor and also on basin tap cold water side, all pipe work is boxed in and may require removing, although after  speaking to latifa appears all floor is the same,
Please carry out annual boiler service.John Doidge (22/10/2025) - Work NoteComplete the annual gas safety of the oven.

Boiler no heating or hot water, Luke Trevatt (23/10/2025) - Work NoteToday I have attended flat 1 where the boiler ie baxi combi 28GA was showing low water pressure issue. The water pressure was toped up to 1.6 Barr gauge and system fully run tested with no further issues to report.
David Collins (22/10/2025) - Work NoteCheck boiler house pumps boilers and controls ok check plant room reset panel and check all pumps on and 2 ports opening.job complete.
David Collins (22/10/2025) - Work NoteTrace fault to panel tripped after power cut, reset panel and check pumps and controls . job complete.

Toilet water leakageLuke Trevatt (24/10/2025) - Work NoteAttended colnorton security toilet, and carried out a full run test inspection of toilet system, checking all seals and connections, at no point did any parts leak and after 6 flushes of system no water leaks were identified, I consulted staff and was agreed no isues. Maybe water was from toilet brush being used and dribbled on to floor,
David Collins (23/10/2025) - Work Notetrace fault to Trend controller unable to rectify put all heating circuits in hand. job complete
David Collins (23/10/2025) - Work NoteTrace fault to gas valve dropped out after fire alarm test, reset gas proving system and check all pumps and boilers running.  job complete.
David Collins (28/10/2025) - Work NoteCheck and remove sink trap clean out replace , run water and check for leaks none found  job complete.
David Collins (28/10/2025) - Work NoteCheck taps and remove air locks , check temps . job complete.
David Collins (29/10/2025) - Work NoteCheck boiler house no faults check plant room controls and pump  air in system vent calorifier.  job complete.
David Collins (30/10/2025) - Work NoteCheck pump and controls free stuck 3port valve . job complete.
David Collins (31/10/2025) - Work NoteIsolate supply and remake joints, turn water back on and check for leaks none found. job complete.
David Collins (15/10/2025) - Work NoteCheck waste for leaks none found check all visible pipe work none visible revisit required. job on going.
David Collins (15/10/2025) - Work NoteCheck pipe runs and dimensions new location of grease trap. job on going .
David Collins (04/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck duct work and trace leak to flue from boiler . Arrange fo flue contractor to visit.  job on going.
David Collins (03/11/2025) - Work NoteTop up pressure on both boilers, turn heating on and adjust all rads as valves to low setting.  job complete.
David Collins (03/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck and free stuck TRV pins vent as required. job complete.
David Collins (03/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck pump and controls vent rads as required.  job complete.
David Collins (03/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck pump and controls found check/ balancing valve shut. Open valve and check heating circulating around building.  job complete.
David Collins (03/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck heating controls and pumps found 3port, trace fault to stuck TRV pins free and vent as required.  job complete.
David Collins (03/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck controls and pumps found 3port stuck, free 3port valve and check operation. job complete
David Collins (03/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck pump and controls trace fault to shut valve, put 3 port in hand to check heating going round all rads.  job complete

Water running into toilet pan constantly.John Doidge (05/11/2025) - Work NoteReplace washer to Ideal Standard toilet cistern fill valve. When toilet is flushed, water leaks from the connection between the pan and the cistern. Both fixing bolts are rusted and will be difficult to undo. The toilet will need to be removed to access the fixings. The fill valve will also be replaced.

No hot water.John Doidge (05/11/2025) - Work NoteThermostat fitted to the immersion element found to have tripped. Reset and check the continuity across the heating element (20 Ohms, indicating that the element is in good condition).

Leaking shower on first floor. Puddle between shower and urinal.John Doidge (05/11/2025) - Work NoteLarge puddle of water in front of the left hand urinal. The waste trap is dry on both urinals. Flush some water down the urinal to find that it is slow to drain away. Possible blockage in the pipework. Ecodrains required to attend.
David Collins (04/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck rads in dining room free stuck pins and vent as required. job complete.
Attend to heatingDavid Collins (04/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck programmer pump and 2port valves , isolate filter and clean refit and check rads heating. job complete
David Collins (04/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck controls and pumps found pump in off position, put in auto and check operation check-boys rooms rads heating.   job complete..
David Collins (04/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck pumps and controls put in hand to check circulation through building. Put controls back in auto and explain to staff. job complete.
David Collins (04/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck all joints and tighten jubilee clips on hoses.  job complete.

Leaking outdoor tap in courtyard area. Luke Trevatt (06/11/2025) - Work NoteToday I attended site and fully tested and inspected the outside courtyard tap. It appears that this has already been looked at at tap was fully tested and did not leak when turned on and off and the male threaded insert to wall connection has had new loctite applied around neck, all connections were fully inspected with no signs of leaks found.
David Collins (06/11/2025) - Work NoteMove furniture to access rad valves , turn of rad as new TRV required replace furniture and arrange revisit.  job on going.
David Collins (05/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck all pipe work and rads above stain on ceiling, remove section of boxing  no leaks found . job complete.
David Collins (05/11/2025) - Work NoteRemove paneling to gain access to water heater check fuse ok. No power to spear trace back to time clock put in over ride. Recheck heater ok.job complete.
David Collins (05/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck rad valves free stuck pins and vent as required. job complete.
David Collins (05/11/2025) - Work NoteTrace leak to float valve isolate toilet remove flush valve and remake joint, fill cistern and check for leaks none found.  job complete.
David Collins (06/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck all taps in boys and staff toilets, free stuck taps as required.  job complete.
David Collins (06/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck plant room pumps and controls no faults found, explain to staff how heating works.  job complete
David Collins (06/11/2025) - Work NoteTrace leak to water cooler isolate water supply and empty machine and dry carpet. Water cooler on hire in from buildings office. job complete
David Collins (10/11/2025) - Work NoteTop up pressure and reset boiler put correct time in programmer, check all rads heating.job complete.
David Collins (10/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck pump and controls put in hand and check all rads heating , free stuck TRVs as necessary. job complete.
David Collins (10/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck rads TRV open trace pipe work and balance system. job complete.
David Collins (10/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck boiler house no faults check plant room trace fault to primary pump tripped , reset and check operation check 2 port valves open. job complete.

Investigate ahu, cutting out, replacement belts and inspect.Luke Trevatt (12/11/2025) - Work NoteToday I attended Queens school and carried out replacement belts on AHU 3/3 I also fully inspected filter, that were changed by Josh on the 8.9 25 these were found in good condition, Ion further investigation the sontay Co 2 sensor was found full of water in casework and the bottom of pcb has water damage this should be sourced and replaced ASAP by controls engineer, the system was left fully operational but in manual mode, as the AHU failed to run in auto mode on inverters, no other isues found although 2x air flow switch hoses require replacement on air intake air flow switch as these are very uv damaged.
David Collins (11/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck water level in tanks, reset pressurisation pumps, check pressure at taps.  job complete.

First floor shower buttons are sticking.John Doidge (13/11/2025) - Work NoteIsolate and replace the push button cartridge to the right hand shower panel. The shower is still running constantly, with little water coming out as a spray to be able to shower. The supplies have been isolated.Unable to remove the shroud around the push button or remove the push button due to corrosion and the allen screw being rounded off. The button does not push in. The supplies to this shower panel have also been isolated. Recommend that both are replaced with new panels. Awaiting price and availability.

Wet patch has appeared on the carpet in the middle of the floor in the bedroom.John Doidge (13/11/2025) - Work NoteLeak traced to a loose radiator valve. Tighten the joint and top up the boiler pressure, which was at zero. Leave a dehumidifier in the bedroom to help dry out the carpet. Tenant has been advised to call to have it collected, or to raise another pink.
David Collins (12/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck shower temperatures in all boys showers and adjust as required.  job complete.

Radiator in bedroom is not working.John Doidge (13/11/2025) - Work NoteSwitch on the central heating and wait for heat to circulate. Check radiators on the first floor. 2 thermostatic pins seem a little stuck. Release both and heat starts to circulate. All radiators on the first floor are now getting hot.
David Collins (13/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck shower waste and sink waste no leaks found, check all visible pipe work no leaks found. job complete.

Leak - Ground floor boys lavatory.Luke Trevatt (17/11/2025) - Work NoteI attended ground floor toilet block where a report of water leaking from being 2 cubicle was reported, I could see moisture along bottom of cased in toilet, although could not gain access due to 5 star key with centre pin, I had to abort at this point as needed to visit office to collect refrigerant and nitrogen for next days work schedule. Apologies.
David Collins (17/11/2025) - Work NoteCheck rads on private side check times and alter start time , floor boards require lifting awaiting asbestos survey.  job on going.

Temperatures of outlets to be tested on a monthly basis. Checking the temperature from the hot tapsUsing an accurate thermometer, check the water flow from a chosen hot tap. When doing this for the first time, the tap furthest away from the calorifier/water heater/boiler should be chosen, this is sometimes called a sentinel outlet.Other representative points can then also be checked in a chosen pattern, eventually repeating the pattern so different taps are checked monthly.Here are the main points to note:Hold the thermometer in the hot water flow for one minuteRecord the temperature on the thermometerIt should be a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius after one minuteIf it is below this, advise whoever oversees the site so the necessary actions can be taken to remedy the issueIf thermostatic mixing valves (TMVs) are fitted, these ensure the temperature never exceeds 44 degrees Celsius primarily to prevent hot water scalding. In this case, the hot water inlet to the TMV should be checked instead of the hot taps. Again, a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius should be recorded in this instance.With a TMV fitted water temperatures at the hot tap should not exceed 44 degrees Celsius.Checking the temperature from water heaters (calorifiers)On a monthly basis check the water flow and return temperatures at water heaters (calorifiers). One way of measuring these temperatures is to use a surface temperature probe. The outgoing water should be at least 60 °C in order to kill Legionella bacteria.Temperatures from cold tapsA similar pattern should be followed to that described for hot water above. Formulate a pattern for rotating through different cold taps each month:Hold the thermometer in the cold water flow for two minutesRecord the temperature after two minutesIt should be a maximum of 20 degrees Celsius or belowReport and action as above if it goes above thisOther water checks to makeMake a monthly check of water temperatures of the flow and return from and to the calorifier (see above).Keeping accurate records is of paramount importance.

Dames flat radiator is not working.John Doidge (05/11/2025) - Work NoteLounge radiator is cold. Both valves are opened fully, with the TRV thermostatic pin moving freely. Replace the TRV head to a second radiator in the bedroom next door, which does not turn off.Balance the heating in the flat in an attempt to get heat through to the cold radiator. On further inspection this radiator appears to be on the same circuit as the one feeding the boys radiators. Access the plant room to find the boys heating pump in fault. Reset the pump and heat begins to circulate.The cold radiator is still cold after 30 minutes. I will return after lunch to see if heat has reached the second floor.
No heating or hot water.

David Collins (03/11/2025) - Work NoteIsolate rad drain and remove from site, cap rad valves and collect dehumidifier .  job complete.

Very load noise when the toilet is flushed.John Doidge (25/11/2025) - Work NoteIsolate the water supply to the cistern to replace the diaphragm washer in the float valve. When re-instating the water supply, it was found that there was no water reaching the cistern. It was suspected to be a faulty isolation valve, which was replaced. Further investigation revealed that a small nut from the bottom of a tap washer had become lodged in the inlet cone within the float valve. The water level was adjusted on completion.
David Collins (05/01/2026) - Work NoteIsolate rad drain and remove from site cap rad valves and dry carpet. job complete.
David Collins (07/01/2026) - Work NoteIsolate rad drain and cap rad valves remove, remove rad from site. job ongoing

Radiator, fallen of wall. third floor, 7Luke Trevatt (13/01/2026) - Work NoteAttended site to a radiator behind a sitting room unit that had come off wat this had been put on by referb contractor in past using light gauge plaster fixings, these had come clean out of wall, radiator fully isolated and drained then fully capped off, this has all been left safe and can be refitted when appropriate fixings are available.
David Collins (19/01/2026) - Work NoteIsolate rad drain and remove from site cap rad valves, wall needs attention by bricky. job complete.

Leaking toilet in the first floor Admissions Office.John Doidge (13/11/2025) - Work NoteReplace the fill valve and flush valve in the toilet cistern. Test for leaks on completion. All now working correctly.

Temperatures of outlets to be tested on a monthly basis. Checking the temperature from the hot tapsUsing an accurate thermometer, check the water flow from a chosen hot tap. When doing this for the first time, the tap furthest away from the calorifier/water heater/boiler should be chosen, this is sometimes called a sentinel outlet.Other representative points can then also be checked in a chosen pattern, eventually repeating the pattern so different taps are checked monthly.Here are the main points to note:Hold the thermometer in the hot water flow for one minuteRecord the temperature on the thermometerIt should be a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius after one minuteIf it is below this, advise whoever oversees the site so the necessary actions can be taken to remedy the issueIf thermostatic mixing valves (TMVs) are fitted, these ensure the temperature never exceeds 44 degrees Celsius primarily to prevent hot water scalding. In this case, the hot water inlet to the TMV should be checked instead of the hot taps. Again, a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius should be recorded in this instance.With a TMV fitted water temperatures at the hot tap should not exceed 44 degrees Celsius.Checking the temperature from water heaters (calorifiers)On a monthly basis check the water flow and return temperatures at water heaters (calorifiers). One way of measuring these temperatures is to use a surface temperature probe. The outgoing water should be at least 60 °C in order to kill Legionella bacteria.Temperatures from cold tapsA similar pattern should be followed to that described for hot water above. Formulate a pattern for rotating through different cold taps each month:Hold the thermometer in the cold water flow for two minutesRecord the temperature after two minutesIt should be a maximum of 20 degrees Celsius or belowReport and action as above if it goes above thisOther water checks to makeMake a monthly check of water temperatures of the flow and return from and to the calorifier (see above).Keeping accurate records is of paramount importance.Asset ID 2849 - Asset Type Water Meter - Service Level Daily - Service Due Date 24/11/2025Asset ID 6107 - Asset Type Water Meter - Service Level Daily - Service Due Date 24/11/2025

Mitchell Groves (14/11/2025) - Work NoteAttended site to install new chatterbox for gas valve.we drilled hole through to gas valve and got cable from the gas valve into the boiler house. Temperatures of outlets to be tested on a monthly basis. Checking the temperature from the hot tapsUsing an accurate thermometer, check the water flow from a chosen hot tap. When doing this for the first time, the tap furthest away from the calorifier/water heater/boiler should be chosen, this is sometimes called a sentinel outlet.Other representative points can then also be checked in a chosen pattern, eventually repeating the pattern so different taps are checked monthly.Here are the main points to note:Hold the thermometer in the hot water flow for one minuteRecord the temperature on the thermometerIt should be a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius after one minuteIf it is below this, advise whoever oversees the site so the necessary actions can be taken to remedy the issueIf thermostatic mixing valves (TMVs) are fitted, these ensure the temperature never exceeds 44 degrees Celsius primarily to prevent hot water scalding. In this case, the hot water inlet to the TMV should be checked instead of the hot taps. Again, a minimum of 50 degrees Celsius should be recorded in this instance.With a TMV fitted water temperatures at the hot tap should not exceed 44 degrees Celsius.Checking the temperature from water heaters (calorifiers)On a monthly basis check the water flow and return temperatures at water heaters (calorifiers). One way of measuring these temperatures is to use a surface temperature probe. The outgoing water should be at least 60 °C in order to kill Legionella bacteria.Temperatures from cold tapsA similar pattern should be followed to that described for hot water above. Formulate a pattern for rotating through different cold taps each month:Hold the thermometer in the cold water flow for two minutesRecord the temperature after two minutesIt should be a maximum of 20 degrees Celsius or belowReport and action as above if it goes above thisOther water checks to makeMake a monthly check of water temperatures of the flow and return from and to the calorifier (see above).Keeping accurate records is of paramount importance.Asset ID 5018 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 29/10/2025Asset ID 5020 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 29/10/2025Asset ID 5022 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 29/10/2025Asset ID 5024 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 29/10/2025Asset ID 5027 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 29/10/2025Asset ID 5029 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 29/10/2025Asset ID 5031 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 29/10/2025Asset ID 5032 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 29/10/2025Asset ID 5035 - Asset Type Water Outlet - Service Level Monthly - Service Due Date 29/10/2025
